title: Bank of America profit falls but beats consensus, as revenue and net interest income rise; Bank of America sees U.S. consumer as 'resilient and strong' but growth is slowing
text:
Revenue increased 8% to $24.5 billion. Net interest income, which reflects profits the bank makes on loans, increased to $13.8 billion from $11.1 billion in the year-ago quarter and ahead of second-quarter net interest income of $12.4 billion, as the bank benefited from higher interest rates.

Bank of America was expected to earn 78 cents a share on revenue of $23.54 billion, according to estimates compiled by FactSet. Analysts projected net interest income of $13.53 billion.

"Our U.S. consumer clients remained resilient with strong, although slower growing, spending levels and still maintained elevated deposit amounts," CEO Brian Moynihan said.

Average loan balances rose 12% to $1 trillion, led by "strong" commercial loan growth as well as higher credit card balances.

The bank reported a net reserve build of $378 million, which gets subtracted from net income, compared to the year-ago period, when the bank released $1.1 billion in reserves to its bottom line.

In a sign of some potential cracks in the financial health of customers, the bank's net charge-offs, which is money it does not expect to collect from outstanding loans, increased 12% to $520 million.

The bank's customers also stepped up spending on their credit cards, with combined credit and debt card spending increasing by 9% to $218 billion.

Client balances in the bank's global wealth and investment management unit fell 12% to $3.2 trillion as rocky financial markets took their toll.

As expected, investment banking revenue fell sharply amid a drop in deal-making compared to the go-go year of 2021. Total investment banking fees decreased by 46% to $1.2 billion.

However, market volatility stoked the bank's markets unit, which booked a 13% increase in trading revenue to $4.1 billion. Within that, fixed income trading revenue rose 27% to $2.6 billion, while equities trading dropped 4% to $1.5 billion.

Shares of Bank of America are down 28.8% in 2022, compared to a 24.8% drop by the S&P 500 SPX and a loss of 20.6% by the Financial Select SPDR Fund XLF.

Bank of America's earnings come after JPMorgan Chase & Co. JPM, Citigroup Inc. C, Morgan Stanley MS and Wells Fargo & Co. WFC all reported lower earnings on Friday.

Goldman Sachs Group Inc. GS is due to report third-quarter earnings on Tuesday.
